title: How to Create Ice Cream With Patterns

steps.headline: Get two or three different flavors of ice cream.
steps.description: You can even try more than three, but the more flavors you get, the longer and more complex it is.

steps.headline: Choose one base flavor.
steps.description: This will be the flavor that you start off with. It will also have a larger quantity than the other flavors.

steps.headline: Melt your base flavor.
steps.description: Leave it out on the table and watch over it, ensuring no bugs come to eat it and stirring the ice cream with a spoon/chopstick every now and then. This process of melting can take as little as 5 minutes to as long as 20, depending on your climate.

steps.headline: Pour your liquid into a desired mould.
steps.description: This will shape up your ice cream nicely.

steps.headline: Put your mould, which should now be filled with melted ice cream, into the freezer (not the fridge).
Wait 1-3 hours.
steps.description: The liquid should take up its original solid shape as edible ice cream.

steps.headline: Set the mould with your ice cream on a flat, hard surface (table, night stand, counter, etc.
Find a butter knife.
steps.description: Delicately carve the desired pattern/shape into your base flavored ice cream. If the ice cream is too hard to be carved into, wait 1 or so minutes.

steps.headline: Put your carved ice cream back into the freezer.
steps.description: After that, take your second flavor (different from the first) and melt it (similar to step 3).

steps.headline: Find a measuring cup.
steps.description: Pour the melted ice cream (second flavor) into the measuring cup.

steps.headline: Take the carved ice cream out of the freezer.
steps.description: Set it beside the measuring cup. Pour the contents of the cup into the carved spaces of the base ice cream.

steps.headline: Set the whole thing back in the freezer.
If desired, repeat steps 9 through 12 with a different flavor.

text: Get two or three different flavors of ice cream. You can even try more than three, but the more flavors you get, the longer and more complex it is. Choose one base flavor. This will be the flavor that you start off with. It will also have a larger quantity than the other flavors. Melt your base flavor. Leave it out on the table and watch over it, ensuring no bugs come to eat it and stirring the ice cream with a spoon/chopstick every now and then. This process of melting can take as little as 5 minutes to as long as 20, depending on your climate. Pour your liquid into a desired mould. This will shape up your ice cream nicely. Put your mould, which should now be filled with melted ice cream, into the freezer (not the fridge).  Wait 1-3 hours. The liquid should take up its original solid shape as edible ice cream. Set the mould with your ice cream on a flat, hard surface (table, night stand, counter, etc. ). Find a butter knife. Delicately carve the desired pattern/shape into your base flavored ice cream. If the ice cream is too hard to be carved into, wait 1 or so minutes. Put your carved ice cream back into the freezer. After that, take your second flavor (different from the first) and melt it (similar to step 3). Find a measuring cup. Pour the melted ice cream (second flavor) into the measuring cup. Take the carved ice cream out of the freezer. Set it beside the measuring cup. Pour the contents of the cup into the carved spaces of the base ice cream. Set the whole thing back in the freezer. Let the liquid freeze. If desired, repeat steps 9 through 12 with a different flavor.  Finished.
